headline.main: The Economic Impact of the Pill

docs.abstract: As economists look at the effect of contraception on the work force, one study found it accounted for 30 percent of the convergence of men's and women's earnings in a 10-year period.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers found that doctors using electronic records ordered expensive imaging tests more often than those relying on paper records.

headline.seo: Digital Records May Not Cut Health Costs, Study Cautions
headline.main: Digital Records May Not Cut Health Costs, Study Cautions
headline.print_headline: Digital Records May Not Cut Health Costs, Study Cautions

docs.abstract: Study in Health Affairs finds computerized patient records are unlikely to cut health care costs and may actually encourage doctors to order expensive tests more often; use of costly image-taking tests has increased sharply in recent years.
docs.snippet: Researchers found that doctors using electronic records ordered expensive imaging tests more often than those relying on paper records.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his new book, the political journalist and columnist Thomas Byrne Edsall argues that fierce partisanship is here to stay in a battle over shrinking resources.
